Preparation and preservation properties of the chitosan coatings modified with the in situ synthesized nano SiOx
Tong Sun a, Chao-ling Wu a, Han Hao b, a, Yue Dai a, Jian-rong Li a, *
a Research Institute of Food Science, Bohai University, Food Safety Key Lab of Liaoning Province, National & Local Joint Engineering Research Center of Storage, Processing and Safety Control Technology for Fresh Agricultural and Aquatic Products, Jinzhou, Liaoning, 121013, China b Hebei Huaqing Environmental Science and Technology Co., ltd., Shijiazhuang, Hebei, 050081, China

http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.foodhyd.2015.09.019 0268-005X/© 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
The chitosan coatings modified with the in situ synthesized nano SiOx were prepared and characterized, and the gas permeabilities and mechanical properties of the chitosan coatings were measured simultaneously. The SiOx dosage affects the micro morphology and microstructure of the chitosan coatings. The results show that in-situ synthesis method is conducive to nano SiOx dispersion. In the coatings, the particles size and amount are increased with nano SiOx dosage, and serious particles aggregation and coarse cross section are presented at nano SiOx dosage of 0.07%. Moreover, the strong hydrogen-bonds are formed between nano SiOx and chitosan molecule, and original structures of the chitosan are disorganized. The nano SiOx connect with chitosan with chemical bonds, and the chitosan structure in C]O bond and amideⅡ are slightly affected. The gas permeabilities and mechanical properties of the coatings are affected by the dosage of nano SiOx, and the optimal nano SiOx dosage is 0.03%. The preservation properties of the chitosan coatings on the Sciaenops ocellatus are remarkable, and that of in situ synthesis nano SiOx chitosan coatings is more superior. Therefore, the chitosan coatings modified by in situ synthesized method may be a promising method to improve the preservation properties of the chitosan coatings.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The chitosan coatings are developed as a promising alternative to commercial preservation coatings for preserving fresh food with the advantages of low cost and ease of processing. In the chitosan coating, chitosan large molecules are bound and dehydrated to generate osmotic coating (Aider, 2010; Azevedo et al., 2014; Campaniello, Bevilacqua, Sinigaglia, & Corbo, 2008; Elsabee & Abdou, 2013). In the process of food preservation, the chitosan coatings suppress transit of oxygen, carbon dioxide and water vapor, and restrain spoilage of food (de Aquino, Blank, & Santana, 2015; Bonilla, Fortunati, Atar es, Chiralt, & Kenny, 2014; Cao, Xue, & Liu, 2009; Fern andez-Saiz, S anchez, Soler, Lagaron, & Ocio, 2013). Conventional chitosan coatings have good antimicrobial properties but have poor mechanical properties and permeability, so the food preservation efficiency is unsatisfactory (Cushen, Kerry, Morris, Cruz-Romero, & Cummins, 2012; Elsabee et al., 2013).
To further improve the food preservation properties of the chitosan coatings, nano particles were introduced to take advantage of their small size effect and surface hydroxyl. The superiority of nano-composited chitosan coatings is that nano particles can uniformly disperse in the chitosan and generate hydrogen bond with chitosan molecules through surface hydroxyl, which means the possibility of providing well mechanical properties and permeability (Shi et al., 2013; Yu et al., 2012). Modification of nanocomposited chitosan coatings recently becomes a research hot spot and critical issue. Related researches show that the preservation efficiency of the chitosan coatings can be improved by adjusting the hydrophile, shape and size of modified nano particles (Wang, Tao, Wang, Shen, & Zhao, 2009). However, the improvement of food preservation efficiency requires not only to control the geometry size and appearance of nanoparticles, but also to set up hydrogen bond connection between nano particles and chitosan. Several oxide materials, such as SiO2, TiO2 and ZnO, have been studied as potential nano materials (Hong, Zhong, & Xue, 2011; Vicentini, Smania, & Laranjeira, 2010; Xie, Wang, Ye, Huang, & Shao, 2012). Among them, SiO2 is considered most promising, which has been shown that the food preservation property of
chitosan coatings could be improved (Yu et al., 2012). However, previous researches on nano-composited chitosan coatings were only on adding nano particles in chitosan solution after surface hydrophile modification (Wang et al., 2009; Xu, Luo, & Xie, 2011). Meanwhile, modified efficiency of the coatings was limited by original size and hydrophile of nano particles. Controlling original size and reducing the modification cost of nano particles is therefore especially important.
In situ synthesis is an effective method to improve the dispersive properties and reduce the size of nano particles in chitosan coatings, which will help improve the mechanical properties and permeability of chitosan coatings in two ways. Firstly, size of nano SiOx will be reduced due to low reactant concentration, leading to enhanced size effect. Secondly, nano SiOx particles are formed in the dehydration process of chitosan, resulting in strong combination of nano SiOx and chitosan molecule. However, the in-situ synthesis nano SiOx composited chitosan coatings were never investigated before. It still remains a question whether in situ synthesis could affect on food preservation properties of chitosan coatings, considering their microstructure, mechanical performances and permeabilities.
In this work, in situ synthesis nano SiOx was designed to modify the chitosan coatings, and Sciaenops ocellatus was chosen to examine the preservation properties of nano-composite coatings. To get the best performance, optimal nano SiOx dosage was investigated.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and Methods
2.1. Materials
sections.text: All the chemical reagents and biological reagents used in this studywere analytically pure, the de-ionizedwater and sterile water with conductivity lower than 0.5 mS/cmwere used to prepare all the solutions. Chitosan was purchased from Shanghai Crystal Pure Biological Technology Co., Ltd (China) with a deacetylation degree of 95% and themolecular weight of 200 kDa. The Sciaenops ocellatus were purchased from the farmers market in Jinzhou City, Liaoning Province, China. The mean weight of the fish was 950 ± 40 g.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of in situ synthesis nano SiOx chitosan coatings
sections.text: The chitosan solution was prepared by dissolving 1.5 g chitosan in 2% (v/v) acetic acid solution of 100 mL at 50 C under vigorous stirring. In the mean time, 1 mol/L sodium silicate solution was dropwise added into 2 mol/L hydrochloric acid solution to adjust the pH value to 4~5, and acidic silicon sol was obtained. With sufficient mixing, a certain amount of acidic silicon sol and 0.3 mL sodium dodecyl benzene sulfonic saturated solutionwere dropwise added into the chitosan solution. After stirring at 50 C for a moment, 0.3 g glycerol was added into the solution. Degassing by ultrasonication at 53 kHz, 224W, at 30 C for 15 min, the in situ synthesis nano SiOx chitosan solution was thus prepared. Then 40 mL of the chitosan solution were poured onto an acrylic board (20 cm 20 cm) and dried at 30 C for 12 h. The coatings were stored in a desiccator for further use.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization of in situ synthesis nano SiOx chitosan coatings
sections.text:
The surface and section micrographs of the chitosan coatings were imaged by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) with the samples gold-sputtercoated for 3 min at 20 kV. The nano particle morphologies in the coatings are measured by field emission scanning electron
microscopy (FETEM, Jem-2100F, JEOL, Japan) with the samples staining, meanwhile, the Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) of the sample was examined. X-ray diffraction were performed using X-ray powder diffractometer (Rigaku Ultima IV, Rigaku, Japan) at a 0.02 step and 2q range of 4 e70 with CuKa radiation, 40 kV, 50mA. The coatings were triturated to powders, and then Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was tested by KBr pellet method (FT-IR, Scimitar 2000 Near FT-IR Spectrometer, Agilent, America), and the spectral range was varied from 4000 to 400 cm 1.

2.4.1. The water-vapor permeability (WVP) of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:

Then the weighting bottles were put in the desiccator, which has a glass of saturated sodium chloride solution of 50 mL on the bottom to provide relative humidity of 60% at room temperature. The cells were weighted every 24 h to a constant weight, and the WVP was calculated according to the equation (1).

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Oxygen permeability (OP) and carbon dioxide permeability (CDP) of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:
The oxygen permeabilities and carbon dioxide permeabilities of the chitosan coatings were measured according to Chinese Standard GB 1038-1970. A sealed plastic casewas used as the circulation cell with an air inlet and outlet, which is length of 30 cm, width of 28 cm and height of 15 cm. Meanwhile, three cylindrical plastic pipes with one open endwere used as measuring cells in the plastic case, which are length of 18 cm and diameter of 6 cm. Firstly, the chitosan coatings were sealed onto the open ends of each measuring cell, and the measuring cells were sealed within the circulation cell. Secondly, a gaseous mixture of CO2/O2 and air from gas cylinders were entered into the circulation cell and issued for 5 min, and then the air inlet and outlet were sealed. Finally, 5 mL gas were extracted from the circulation cell and discarded, and then the other gas of 10 mL were imported into the O2/CO2 detector (CYES-Ⅱ, Shanghai Jiading Student Federation Industrial Co, Ltd., China) to measure the percentage of oxygen or carbon dioxide. After that, the circulation cell was opened, and the gas of 10mLwas extracted from the measuring cell to measure the percentage of oxygen or carbon dioxide. OP and CDP were calculated according to the equations (2) and (3).
OP ¼ VO2 d A DP (2)
CDP ¼ VCO2 d A DP (3)
Where, OP is oxygen permeability of the chitosan coatings, mL$cm/ (kPa$d$cm2); CDP is carbon dioxide permeability of the chitosan
coatings, mL$cm/(kPa$d$cm2); VCO2 is the volume of carbon dioxide permeating the coatings in 24 h, mL; VO2 is the volume of oxygen permeating the coatings in 24 h, mL; d is average thickness of the coatings, cm; A is the effective area of the coatings, cm2; DP is the pressure differential between the circulating cell and measuring cell, kPa.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. The mechanical properties of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:
The tensile strength (Ts) and elongation at break (EB) were determined according to the method of Antoniou (Antoniou, Liu, Majeed, & Zhong, 2015). A coating with length of 70 mm and width of 25 mmwas tested by texture analyser (TA-XT-PLUS (SMS), Stable Micro System, US) with a load cell of 20 kg. The initial grip gap between the clamps was 40 mm and the cross-head speed was 2.0 mm/min. The Ts and EB were calculated according to the equations (4) and (5).

sections.heading: 2.5. Preservation properties measurement of the chitosan coatings to Sciaenops ocellatus
2.5.1. Coating treatment of Sciaenops ocellatus
sections.text: After frozen to death, Sciaenops ocellatus were divided into several groups randomly, and then Sciaenops ocellatuswere painted different kinds of the coating solution except the control group. Airdry Sciaenops ocellatuswere put into retort pouches and sealed, and then preserved at 4 C in the refrigerator. During the preservation, the freshness indexes of fish Sciaenops ocellatus were measured to evaluate the preservation properties of the chitosan coatings.

sections.heading: 2.5.2. The freshness index measurement of Sciaenops ocellatus
sections.text:
2.5.2.1. Determination of pH. The minced Sciaenops ocellatus muscle of 5.0 g weremixed with 50.0mL of distilled water, and then the mixturewere homogenized and filtered. After 30 min, the pH value of the filter liquor was determined.
2.5.2.2. Determination of Thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS). The TBARS were determined by the method of Porkony and Dieffenbacher, as described by Kirk and Sawyer (1991). After homogenizing the mixture of 10.0 g minced Sciaenops ocellatus muscle and 25 mL deionized water, 25 mL 5% trichloroacetic acid was added and stirred evenly. Let it stand for 30 min, the turbid solution was filtered. Then 5 mL of 0.02 mol/L thiobarbituric acid was mixed with 5 mL supernatant liquid, and the mixture was heated at 80 C for 40 min to color. The absorbance was measured at 532 nm after cooling to room temperature. A blank agent was run at the same time. TBARS value was calculated according to the equation (6).

2.5.2.4. Determination of K-value. All operations were at 0~4 C. After filtering with filter membrane of 0.45 mm, the solution was quickly frozen and stored at 80 C for HPLC analysis. The determination conditions of HPLC analysis were: the chromatographic columnwas BDS C18 (250 mm 44.6 mm); moving phase was the mixed liquor of 0.04 mol/L monopotassium phosphate and 0.06 mol/L dipotassium phosphate; the sampling amount was 1 mL; the flow ratewas 1mL/min; the column temperaturewas 37 C; the test wavelength was 254 nm. 2.5.2.5. Determination of Total viable counts (TVC). Ten grams of minced fish meat was homogenized with sterilized saline water of 90 mL for 1 min in the sterilized retort pouch. After 10 times series dilution of the homogeneous liquid, 1 mL dilutions and 20 mL plate count agar were transferred into the culture dish. The samples were stood for solidification and incubated at 37 C for 72 h. Finally, TVC was counted.
2.5.2.6. Sensory evaluation of Sciaenops ocellatus. Sensory evaluation of Sciaenops ocellatuswere assessed by five professional staff in a laboratory according the method of De-cheng Fu (Fu et al., 1991) in 4 aspects, these are eyeball, body surface, muscle texture and odor. The sensory evaluation standard is shown in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.5.3. Texture determination of Sciaenops ocellatus
sections.text:
The textures of Sciaenops ocellatus were measured by texture analyzer (TA-XT-PLUS (SMS), Stable Micro System, US) at 25 C, including hardness, chewiness, springiness and resilience. Texture profile analyses were carried out according to the method of Li (Li et al., 2012). The cubic fish meat without skin was used, a P/50R probe simulated a human finger, and the speed of the P/50R probe was 1 mm/s. Each sample was compressed twice with a vertical strain of 50%, and an interval time of per cycle is 5 s.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
3.1. Characterization of the chitosan coatings
3.1.1. Micro morphologies of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:
As food preservation materials, the microstructure of chitosan coatings will not only determine their physicochemical properties, but also affect their food preservation performances. Generally, nanoparticles may result in preferable food preservation performances of coatings, but it is possible for destroying their microstructure. However, primitive size and hydrophilic properties of nanoparticles restrict their dispersing in the coatings, and then limit improvement of the food preservation performances. Therefore, an optimal dispersing of nanoparticles in the coatings should be pursued for improving the physicochemical properties of the coatings. In this work, the chitosan coatings modified with nano SiOx were prepared by in-situ synthesis method, and the SEM imagines of the chitosan coatings with different nano SiOx dosage are shown in Fig. 1. There are graininess in all chitosan coatings. Meanwhile, the particles size and amount are increased with nano SiOx dosage, and serious particles aggregation and coarse cross section are presented at the nano SiOx dosage of 0.07%. The
Fig. 1. SEM images of the cross sections (aee) and the surface (f) of the chitosan coatings wit 0.03%.
graininess include two parts, one is chitosan molecules scattered unevenly and reunited, the other is nano SiOx particles formed from silica sol gradually dehydration in the coating formation process. The excellent bone structure and high stiffness of the silica gel could inhibit severe shrinkage and collapsing structure of materials by improving the mechanical properties of chitosan (Lai, Yang, Chen, & Hsiao, 2006). Figs. 1(aee) show that apparent cracks appear in the cross section of the pure chitosan coating, but no crack in the chitosan coatings modified with nano SiOx. It is may be that the stress loss of coating dehydration are weakened by nanometer particles in the coatings formation process.
To investigate the detailed structure of nanoparticles in the coating with 0.03% nano SiOx, TEM was performed for stained coating, and the crystal structure of the nanoparticle are examined by SAED (Fig. 2). Fig 2(a) shows that the particles of 10e30 nm are disperse uniformly in the coating, illustrating that in-situ synthesis method is conducive to nano SiOx dispersion. SAED result show the nanoparticles are amorphous state (Fig. 2(b)). Furthermore, the energy spectrum analysis (EDS) results clarify the particles SiOx (SFig. 1, see Supplementary materials).

sections.heading: 3.1.2. XRD characterization of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:
The crystalline nature of the chitosan coatings with or without in-situ synthesis SiOx was tested by XRD (Fig. 3). The broad peak at 2q ¼ 24.2 is assigned to amorphous SiOx, and the peak at 2q ¼ 20 is attributed to chitosan (Jia, Hou, Wei, Xu,& Liu, 2008). XRD results show that the broad peak appears at 2q ¼ 20.3 in the chitosan coating without in-situ synthesis SiOx, and the crystallinity degree is about 70%. Meanwhile, the peaks shift to big angle and the

It may be due to overlapping peaks of nano SiOx and chitosan. Moreover, it is indicated the strong hydrogen-bond are formed between nano SiOx and chitosan molecule due to more hydroxyl on nano SiOx surface, and original structure of the chitosan are disorganized.

sections.heading: 3.1.3. FT-IR spectra of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:
FT-IR spectra were performed to investigate the detail chemical bonds structure of the chitosan coatings, as shown in Fig. 4. The medium intensity wide peaks at 3500-3300 cm 1 correspond to stretching vibration of non-associated OeH and NeH, and theweak peaks at 2927 cm 1 and 2869 cm 1 attribute to stretching vibration of CeH in methyl or methenyl. The peaks at 2359 cm 1 and 2338 cm 1 are due to CO2. The peaks at 1650 cm 1, 1560 cm 1 and 1332 cm 1 are characteristic absorption peaks of amideⅠ, amideⅡ and amide Ⅲ respectively, according to the published literature (Ren, Bao, Wang, & Ma, 2006). Meanwhile, the peak at 1512 cm 1 belongs to NeH stretching vibration of free amino generate from chitosan deacetylation (Qi, Xu, Jiang, Hu, & Zou, 2004). The peak at 1429 cm 1 is due to stretching vibration of C]O, and the peaks at 1454 cm 1 and 1154 cm 1 are characteristic absorption peaks of CeH and b-glucosidic bond respectively (Qi et al., 2004). The peak
at 668 cm 1 is sensitive absorption peaks of chitosan crystal. As shown in Figs. 4(bee), the peaks presented at 1257 cm 1, 989 cm 1, 923 cm 1, 565 cm 1 and 472 cm 1 are due to in-situ synthesis nano SiOx, and the peak intensity of 1072 cm 1 peak increase with the nano SiOx dosage. As the published literature indicated, the peaks at 1257 cm 1 and 989 cm 1 attribute to stretching vibration and bending vibration of SieC (Yong et al., 2000), the peaks at 1072 cm 1, 565 cm 1 attribute to stretching vibration and bending vibration of SieO, the peaks at 923 cm 1 is due to SieH, the peaks at 858 cm 1 is due to SieN, the peaks at 472 cm 1 attributes to bending vibration of SieOeSi (Wang et al., 2009; Zheng, Huang, & Wei, 2009). In addition, the peaks 1429 cm 1 and 1560 cm 1 increase obviously with the dosage of in-situ synthesis nano SiOx, suggesting that nano SiOx connect with chitosan with chemical bonds, and the chitosan structure in C]O bond and amideⅡ are slightly affected. By in-situ synthesis method, nano SiOx are formed with chitosan dehydration simultaneously, so eOH on the surface of nano SiOx forms hydrogen bond with active group of chitosan. In-situ synthesis methodmakes it possible to improve dispersion of nano particles and enhance the properties of nano composited chitosan coatings.

sections.heading: 3.2. The properties of the chitosan coatings
3.2.1. The gas permeabilities of the chitosan coatings
sections.text: The preservation properties are affected by the gas permeabilities of the coatings, and gas transfer behavior in composited coatings is a penetration diffusion course of sole molecular. In the sealed condition, gas will dissolve in the coatings on the high partial pressure side firstly, and then gas molecules seize the moment hole driven by differential pressure, which generate due to strenuous exercising of macromolecular chain of the coatings. Afterwards, the gas molecules permeate gradually along this passageway, and evaporate from the low partial pressure side finally. The gas permeabilities of the coatings are characterized by WVP, OP and CDP in Fig. 5. The results show that the gas permeabilities decrease with the dose of nano SiOx, and then increase significantly (P < 0.05). TheminimumWVP and CDP are at the nano SiOx of 0.05%, and theminimumOP is at the nano SiOxof 0.03%. The hydrogen-bond interaction of the chitosan and hydroxyl on the surface of in-situ SiOx adjusts the dissolving, diffusing and evaporation degree of gas in the coating. Meanwhile, the dispersed nanoparticles change the micropore structure of the chitosan coatings, so the gas permeabilities decrease with the dose of nano SiOx. However, when the in-situ SiOx is excessive, part of particles are severely agglomerated due to nonuniform dispersion. So the hydrogen-bond interaction reduces and the micropore structure of the chitosan coatings changes, resulting in the gas permeabilities of the coatings increase.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. The mechanical properties of the chitosan coatings
sections.text:
As shown in Fig. 6, Ts and EB of the coatings increase with the
dosage of nano SiOx, and then decrease significantly (P < 0.05). The optimalmechanical properties are at the nano SiOx of 0.03%. The insitu nano SiOx well adsorb and bond with chitosan in the coatings formation, so the interphase adhesion strength between matrix and nano particles enhances. This is in favor of stress transmission, leading to the mechanical properties of the coatings are improved. However, excessive amounts of in-situ nano SiOx cause obvious deterioration in the dispersion of nano particles, and the nano particles is inclined to agglomerate. Under the action of external force, the reunion particles would slip due to surface defect, resulting in poor mechanical properties of the chitosan coatings.

sections.heading: 3.3. Presevation properties of the chitosan coatings to Sciaenops ocellatus
3.3.1. Freshness index of Sciaenops ocellatus
sections.text:
To research the influence of in situ synthesis nano SiOx on the chitosan coatings, the preservation properties of the coatings to Sciaenops ocellatus at 4 C are measured, and the results are shown in Fig. 7.
The pH value of Sciaenops ocellatus decreases initially and then increases with the storage duration (Fig. 7(a)). Usually, the internal glycogen of Sciaenops ocellatus degrades to acid, such as lactic acid after the aquatic livestock death, so the pH of muscle decreases. Soon afterward, with the action of itself enzyme and microorganism, the protein, amino and other nitrogen substance are decomposed into alkaline matter, such as ammonia, trimethylamine, benzpyrole and histamine, so the pH of muscle increases subsequently. Theminimum pH value of the control group presents at 4 days, and presents at 8 days for the coatings group. The results

are similar to that reported for refrigerated drum (T. Li, Li, Hu, & Li, 2013). It means that the chitosan coatings effectively retard the degradation of the internal glycogen of Sciaenops ocellatus. With the chitosan coatings on the Sciaenops ocellatus, the coatings effectively slow the microorganism growth, and prevent the oxygen into fish body. So the glycolysis is inhibited, and the generation of lactic acid is slowed down. During storage, the pH of the control sample is higher than that of the coatings group, indicating that the chitosan coatings restrain effectively micro-biological degradation and enzymolysis, so reduce the degradation nitrogen substance. In the later storage duration, with in situ synthesized SiOx chitosan coatings, the pH of the Sciaenops ocellatus is lower than that of without in situ synthesized SiOx. It shows that the in situ synthesized SiOx chitosan coatings act as barriers for internal nitrogen
substance degradation. The mechanical properties and gas permeabilities of the chitosan coatings are improved by the in situ synthesized SiOx, so that the exchange of materials between fish and environment is inhibited. Therefore, the microorganism is inhibited, and diffusion of oxygen and vapor are weakened effectively from air to fish body.
To characterize the rancidity degree of aquatic product fat oxidation, TBA values are measured. TBA values of Sciaenops ocellatus increase gradually during storage, and the TBA values with chitosan coatings is lower than that of control group (Fig. 7(b)), indicating that the chitosan coatings hinder oxygen enter into fish body from the environment, thus the fat oxidation are postponed. Meanwhile, the chitosan coating with in situ synthesized nano SiOx chitosan, the TBA values are lower than that of without nano SiOx,
illustrating that in situ synthesized nano SiOx improve the gas regulation function of the chitosan coatings, and oxygen permeability of the coatings is reduced.
The total volatile basic nitrogen (TVB-N) is usually used to evaluate the spoilage metamorphic grade of aquatic product. During storage, the protein was decomposed into alkaline volatile substance such as amine and ammonia by enzyme and bacterium. According to GB/T5009.45-2003 (China), the first class freshness indicator is lower than 13 mg/100 g, the second class freshness indicator is lower than 30 mg/100 g. Fig. 7(c) shows that TVB-N value of Sciaenops ocellatus increase gradually with storage, and the TVB-N value with chitosan coatings are lower than that of control group. It may be that the chitosan delays the bacterium growth due to its antibacterial properties, thus reducing the protein decomposed performance of bacterium. However, there is no striking distinction in TVB-N values for chitosan coatings group with or without in situ synthesized nano SiOx, indicating that in situ synthesized nano SiOx does not affect the antibacterial properties of the chitosan.
K-value is defined as the ratio ( 100) of non-phosphorylated ATP breakdown products to the total ATP breakdown products, which is used as a freshness index in fish species, and the fresh fish has low K-value. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the K-value of Sciaenops ocellatus increases with the storage. Meanwhile, the K-value with the chitosan coatings is lower than that of control group, and the Kvalue is the lowest with in situ synthesized nano SiOx chitosan coatings. The excellent mechanical properties and gas permeabilities of the chitosan coatings slow the interchange of materials between fish body and environment, resulting in ATP enzyme activity reduces. optimal with in situ synthesized nano SiOx chitosan coatings. Total viable counts (TVC) has been used to evaluate freshness of seafood (T. Li et al., 2013), and the TVC changes of Sciaenops ocellatus are presented in Fig. 7(e). The TVC of the different group increases by varying degrees during storage. The control group exceeds the 7 log CFU/g for TVC on the 8th day of storage, which is regarded as the upper acceptability limit for raw fish (T. Li et al., 2013). However, with the chitosan coatings, TVC of the samples become more than 7 log CFU/g on the 16th day of storage, indicating that the chitosan coatings restrain bacterium growth effectively. The results show that in situ synthesized nano SiOx has not improved the antibacterial properties of the chitosan coatings, the results is associated to the results of TVB-N, confirming that the putrefying bacteria acts as a main influencing factor to decomposing of protein.
The sensory assessments of Sciaenops ocellatus are shown in Fig. 7(f). The sensory scores decrease with the storage. During the storage, the muscle gets soft and the odor become smelly. Comparing with the control group, the sensory scores with the chitosan coatings decrease slower. The corruption of Sciaenops ocellatus is delayed by the chitosan coatings due to their antibacterial properties and excellent gas permeabilities. Meanwhile, with in situ synthesized nano SiOx, the sensory scores of Sciaenops ocellatus are the highest.

The results show that the hardness, springness, chewiness and resilience of Sciaenops ocellatus are all decrease with the storage, and all texture index decrease slowly with the chitosan coatings. Meanwhile, the in situ synthesized nano SiOx improves effectively the springness and resilience of Sciaenops ocellatus (see Fig. 8).
The chitosan forms the compact coatings on the surface of Sciaenops ocellatus, so the material interchanges of fish body and outsides are prevented effectively, which reduces gas permeation and restrains the growth of microorganism in the fish body. Therefore, the glycogen degradation, oxidation rancidity, its protein decomposition and ATP decomposition are suppressed. The in situ synthesized nano SiOx uniformly disperse in the chitosan, and combine with the chitosan by chemical bonds and hydrogen bonds. So the improved microstructures, the strengthened mechanical properties and the lowered gas permeation performances of the coatings make the texture change of Sciaenops ocellatus slower in the storage stage.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: The micro morphology and microstructure of the chitosan coatings were improved by in situ synthesized nano SiOx. Moreover, its gas permeabilities and mechanical properties are affected by nano SiOx dosage, and the coating is optimal with 0.03% of nano SiOx. In situ synthesis method is conducive to nano SiOx dispersion, the strong hydrogen-bond are formed between nano SiOx and chitosan molecule, and original structure of the chitosan are disorganized. The preservation properties of the chitosan coatings on the Sciaenops ocellatus are remarkable, and that of in situ synthesis nano SiOx chitosan coatings is more superior. This research would have potential applications on food preservation.

metadata.abstractText: The chitosan coatings modified with the in situ synthesized nano SiOx were prepared and characterized, and the gas permeabilities and mechanical properties of the chitosan coatings were measured simultaneously. The SiOx dosage affects the micro morphology and microstructure of the chitosan coatings. The results show that in-situ synthesis method is conducive to nano SiOx dispersion. In the coatings, the particles size and amount are increased with nano SiOx dosage, and serious particles aggregation and coarse cross section are presented at nano SiOx dosage of 0.07%. Moreover, the strong hydrogen-bonds are formed between nano SiOx and chitosan molecule, and original structures of the chitosan are disorganized. The nano SiOx connect with chitosan with chemical bonds, and the chitosan structure in C]O bond and amideII are slightly affected. The gas permeabilities and mechanical properties of the coatings are affected by the dosage of nano SiOx, and the optimal nano SiOx dosage is 0.03%. The preservation properties of the chitosan coatings on the Sciaenops ocellatus are remarkable, and that of in situ synthesis nano SiOx chitosan coatings is more superior. Therefore, the chitosan coatings modified by in situ synthesized method may be a promising method to improve the preservation properties of the chitosan coatings. © 2015 Elsevier Ltd.
